column9: Initiative from the undisclosed GRI (found by the coder but not mentioned in the GRI index table)

column6: Entities included in the organization's sustainability reporting
column7: Westpac's report included Asgard Capital Management Limited, St. George Finance Holdings Ltd, and BT Funds Management Limited.

column6: Reporting period, frequency, and contact point
column7: Westpac's report covers its performance from 1 October 2022 to 30 September 2023.
All restatements have been highlighted within the relevant data sheets, including footnotes to explain the reason for restatement.
PwC provided external assurance for Westpac's report.

column6: Activities, value chain and other business relationships
column7: Westpac provides financial products and services.

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Westpac's Director Appointment & Board Renewal Policy limits the tenure of Non-executive Directors, other than the Chairman, to nine years from the date first elected by shareholders. The maximum tenure for the Chairman is 12 years, including any term served previously as a Director, from the date first elected by shareholders.
column20: Director Appointment & Board Renewal Policy, Non-Executive Director, shareholder

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: New Directors receive an induction pack and letter of appointment setting out the expectations of the role and conditions of appointment, including the expected term of appointment and remuneration. This letter aligns with the ASXCGC Recommendations. All new Directors participate in an induction program to familiarise themselves with Westpac's business and strategy, culture and values and any current issues before the Board and the Board Committees.
column20: Induction pack, letter of appointment, remuneration

column6: Nomination and selection of the highest governance body
column13: Westpac's Board-approved Group Fit and Proper Policy (F&P Policy) outlines how it assesses the fitness and propriety of its Directors, Accountable Persons under BEAR, and other individuals in key positions of responsibility. The F&P Policy supports Westpac in complying with APRA Prudential Standards CPS 520 and SPS 520, the Banking Act 1959 (Cth) (including BEAR), Superannuation Industry (Supervision) Act 1993 (Cth), relevant ASIC licensing requirements (Australian Financial Services Licence and Australian Credit Licence) and equivalent offshore regulations as applicable.
column20: Fit and Proper Policy, Director, Accountable Person

column6: Chair of the highest governance body
column7: Mr John McFarlane is the chair of Westpac's Board.

column6: Role of the highest governance body in overseeing the management of impacts
column7: The Board provides leadership and strategic guidance for Westpac and its related corporate bodies, in addition to overseeing the sound and prudent management of the Group.

column6: Delegation of responsibility for managing impacts
column13: The Delegated Authority Policy Framework outlines the principles Westpac has adopted to govern decision-making within the Westpac Group, including escalation channels and reporting to the Board. The scope of, and limitations to, authority delegated by the Board to the CEO and through the CEO to other Group Executives is articulated in formal delegation instruments and covers areas such as expenditure, funding and securitisation, and lending.
column20: Delegated Authority Policy Framework, formal delegation, CEO

column6: Role of the highest governance body in sustainability reporting
column13: Corporate governance is the framework of systems, policies and processes by which Westpac operates and through which its people are empowered and accountable for making decisions that affect its business, operations, customers and stakeholders. The framework establishes the roles and responsibilities of Westpac's Board, management team, employees and suppliers. It also establishes the systems, policies, and processes for monitoring and evaluating Board and management performance and the practices for corporate reporting, disclosure, remuneration, risk management, and engagement of security holders.

Westpac's conflicts of interest framework is designed to identify and manage actual, potential and perceived conflicts of interest. The conflicts of interest framework includes the Group Conflicts of Interest Policy and supporting policies, standards and procedures.
column20: Conflicts of interest framework, conflict of interest, Conflicts of Interest Policy

column13: The Board assesses the independence of Westpac's Non-executive Directors on appointment and annually. Each Non-executive Director provides an annual attestation of their interests and independence. Directors are considered to be independent if they are independent of management and free from any business or other relationship that could materially interfere with or could reasonably be perceived to interfere with their judgment materially.

Westpac's Speaking Up Policy encourages employees, contractors, secondees, former employees, brokers, service providers and suppliers to raise any concerns about activities or behaviours that may be unlawful or unethical. Concerns can be raised anonymously using Westpac's reporting system' Concern Online' and the Whistleblower Hotline.
column20: Speaking Up Policy, concern, Concern Online

column6: Collective knowledge of the highest governance body
column13: Westpac's Directors have a broad range of relevant financial and other skills, knowledge and experience, which helps guide the Group. The Board uses a skills matrix to illustrate the key skills and experience it seeks to achieve in its membership collectively and the number of Directors with each skill and experience. The skills matrix also assists in identifying focus areas for the continued education and professional development of Directors.

column6: Evaluation of the performance of the highest governance body
column13: The Board undertakes ongoing self-assessment and an annual performance review, which an independent consultant periodically conducts. The review process includes assessing the performance of the Board, the Board Committees and each Director, with outputs collected, analysed and presented to the Board.
column20: Self-assessment, annual performance review, independent consultant

column13: The Group remuneration policy sets out the design and management of remuneration arrangements across Westpac. An established governance structure, plans and frameworks support the policy. The policy supports Westpac's compliance with legal and regulatory requirements.
column20: Group remuneration policy, remuneration arrangement, regulatory requirement

column7: The Board has overall accountability for the remuneration framework and its application.
The ratio of the annual total compensation for the highest-paid individual to the median annual total compensation for all employees (excluding the highest-paid individual) is 65:1.

"In closing, I genuinely believe we have made progress as a Group, that we have seen the worst, but still require further simplification. Notwithstanding near-term uncertainties on the economic front, and increased technology rationalisation requiring investment, looking beyond that, I do believe for Westpac, the best is yet to come."

column8: Customer Outcome and Risk Excellence Program
column13: In 2020, Westpac commenced the Customer Outcome and Risk Excellence program (CORE) to address risk management deficiencies identified by Westpac's assessments and by regulators' findings. It includes the Australian Prudential Regulation Authority's (APRA's) Risk Governance Review, completed in December 2020, which resulted in a court-enforceable undertaking agreed with APRA. The Board oversees CORE, with the executive team accountable for delivery. Outcomes have been incorporated into executive remuneration decisions.
column20: Customer Outcome and Risk Excellence Program, Risk Management Deficiency, Risk Governance Review

column13: Westpac's Risk Management Framework outlines its approach to managing risk across the Group, bringing together systems, structures, policies, processes and people. A strong risk culture and the Three Lines of Defence model with customers at the centre underpin the framework. These elements operate independently and interactively to provide a complete risk management approach and to deliver fair customer outcomes. Westpac regularly reviews each element to ensure the framework is operating effectively.
column20: Risk Management Framework, risk culture, customer outcome

column13: Westpac's Code of Conduct sets out a consistent standard and establishes the expectations of its people to do what is right. The Code goes beyond an obligation to comply with laws and policies. It is a key aspect of improving conduct to ensure fair outcomes for customers, communities and each other.
column20: Code of Conduct, standard, law, policy

column6: Mechanisms for seeking advice and raising concern
column13: Westpac's Whistleblower Protection Officers are responsible for protecting whistleblowers concerned that they may experience detrimental conduct because of speaking up. They also engage directly with whistleblowers to address risks of reprisal. Whistleblowers may also raise a concern directly with a Whistleblower Protection Officer.
column20: Whistleblower Protection Officers, whistleblower, detrimental conduct

column13: Westpac's Group Securities Trading Policy prohibits Directors, employees, secondees and contractors from dealing in any securities and other financial products they possess inside information. They are also prohibited from passing on inside information to others who may use it to trade in securities or from procuring others to trade.
column20: Securities Trading Policy, financial product, inside information

column13: Westpac continued to enforce a Global Sanctions Policy and sanctions compliance framework. They ensure that Westpac does not have banking relationships with or facilitate any transactions involving individuals and entities that are the subject of sanctions designations due to involvement in modern slavery-related activities or human rights abuses.
column20: Global Sanctions Policy, sanctions compliance framework, sanctions designation

column7: Westpac participates in several voluntary sustainability initiatives, including the Global Reporting Initiative (GRI), the Equator Principles, the Principles for Responsible Banking, the Net Zero Banking Alliance, the United Nations Global Compact, the RE100, the Sustainability Accounting Standards Board (SASB), the Taskforce on Nature-related Financial Disclosures (TNFD) and the Australian Government Climate Active Carbon Neutral Standard for Organisations.
